content.description: Pull through a tough low bulge on crimps and regain your composure.   The finish up on the headwall on more mellow jugs pulling. Not a great warm up due to the crimpy start
content.location: Starts on the right side of the wall.

climbs.name: The Unholey
climbs.fa: Blake Bowling, Equipped by Ian Kirk

content.description: Boulder your way through a series of sequential shallow pockets to a good rest. It's not over though as you have to get established on the upper headwall.   Congratulate yourself on your badassery and finish it up.
content.location: This is last route on the Unholey Wall before the wall blanks out.  The route is next to a beautiful holler often with a waterfall to keep you company

content.description: This route is similar in character to it's neighbor, except with a bulge to pull adds a bit of difficulty.  Originally FA'd by a visiting Welsh, the route name translates to "big hole".
content.location: Starts on the small ledge just right of The Hole 9 yards.

content.description: Fun and unique line. Tech your way up the arete using the the side of the massive hueco as long as possible. Make some thin balancey moves for a few bolts and finish on easier terrain to the anchors.
content.location: This route follows the arete just left of a massive hueco that you  can walk in to.

content.description: Climb a couple moves to a small ledge and figure out how to reach a high crimp.   Continue climbing through a mixture of crimps and jugs that eases up closer to anchors.
content.location: Start middle of the wall to the right of the large floor level hueco.

content.description: Start out with a nice  5.9 pocketed face that leads to a no hands stance under the steep stuff. Clip the perma on the left and launch into pocket pulling that leads to a rail. Traverse left, pull the well defined crux and then power your way to the anchors.
content.location: Starts directly in middle between to large huecos up on the headwall.

content.description: Shares the start with Holey Terror. Once you get to steep headwall boulder through a low problem.   Then continue traversing right until you come to a heart break crux going to the anchors.
content.location: Starts on pocketed face directly between to large hueco's on the upper wall.

content.description: Sustained crimping from the 1st bolt to the last bolt with a slopey ledge midway that is tough to get above.. If you get through all that, you are rewarded with jug runnels to finish up on. If you're worried about the fall going to the last bolt... it's tested and safe, assuming if your belayer has a pulse.
content.location: This is the first route to the right of a large, ground level hueco

content.description: This is short route on nice golden rock that get's easier as you go.
content.location: First route on a small ledge as you come up the trail from the A-Hole Wall, where a large tree has fallen over.

content.description: Work up to low bulge using a good but often wet sidepull.  Tick tack through crimps and edges where hold size improves near the end.
content.location: This starts about 20 feet right of the large ground level hueco.
